description: After weeks of unrest and rising calls for accountability, Nikola Petrak formally endorses the creation of public citizen juries to investigate the BCI and Council actions. Using his old credentials and contacts, he ensures these proceedings are widely publicized and protected from interference.

Citizen juries begin open hearings, gathering testimony and evidence from residents, technical experts, and whistleblowers. Revelations about wrongful denials, disappearances, and Halden’s secret BCI directives generate widespread outrage and support for deep change.

Rada Miskovic and Sven Halek disclose decrypted logs showing Halden installed a hidden fail-safe: if enough evidence of abuse is presented publicly, the BCI will auto-deactivate. Public attention shifts to the jury’s final verdict.

Citizen juries vote to declare the BCI 'guilty' of systemic harm. In response, the system issues a final city-wide message of apology before disabling all scoring functions, confirming Halden’s fail-safe was real.

With the BCI gone, grassroots assemblies and local organizations mobilize to coordinate essential services and maintain order. Stenograd quickly adapts to an era of decentralized governance, facing confusion but newfound community autonomy.
